reviews.review_text: After all the bad press surrounding slapping the famous XCOM (sic.) brand on a TPS there is a surprising decent game left behind. You are Agent Carter, a cynical broken man thrust into the limelight after an Alien invasion now tasked as the tip of the spear against this new threat.  There are many elements and ideas drawn from the previous games but it is a strictly linear and pre determined experience. You operate out of XCOM headquarters between the main story missions. You have free run of the base and are able to go on minor side missions, perform investigations inside the base and sent agents out on missions on their own to gain experience and new equipment. Sadly even though the base has vast Engineering and Lab sections, they are cosmetic. You can't perform research on new equipment or ideas or perform autopsies. The only way to get new equipment is to find it during a mission and the only way to learn about various elements is to click on one of the copious clickables in the world.  Carter can bring two additional henchmen with him on a mission from one of the four classes. They are all pretty standard tropes from other games but do add an interesting element to the game. Do you go all out attack with commandos and snipers, sit back and dig in with engineers and support specialists or a combination of the four. You can move henchmen around the battleground, conveniently littered with waist high walls, flank enemies and use the various abilities in conjunction with Carter's unique ones for a multitude of strategies. But...  A warning: The friendly henchmen AI is some of the worst you'll ever see. They'll jump out of cover, run left, run right, turn a full circle, jump over another wall landing right next the nearest enemy before coming back to you. They need to be babysat at all times or they will be useless.  Where the game shines is in the fantastic recreation of cold-war early sixties America and the digital acting. The influence of Mass Effect is obvious but still welcome and the story? Well, let's just say it takes quite the left turn near the end!  Update for badge!  I'll give it 7.5/10 on the AAA scale of 7-10

Like a fair number of other games today XCOM Declassified is a case of the mistaken identity. Bureau is a great game solid 3D person action with surprisingly deep tactical elements, great visuals, and nice (for the pulp genre) story.   The problem is the game has a lot more in common with Mass Effect than with XCom.   Combat, squad management, agent powers, level design... everything is patterned after Mass Effect. Even story really - loose team-building part, replace Reapers with Outsiders, replace indoctrination with infection... few more similar changes... put the whole thing on 1960s Earth = Mass Effect Deja Vu.  The bottom line, if you are looking for an XCom game - you might as well pass. If Mass Effect streamlined for combat missions and set in 60s sounds interesting - the game is more than worth the price tag.  Note: Keep in mind the game really is tactical, on anything but the easiest difficulty expect to spend more of your time commanding the squad than pulling a trigger.

Definitely worth a buy though, as long as your expectations are right.

A third person Mass Effect interpretation of XCOM. It uses a lot of the mechanics and lore from the Enemy Unknown relaunch. Still not as good as the original.   No base building, research, or anything that you associate with XCOM games. The missions are very linear. There's not much variation you can really employ.   Lot of small touches to add to immersive experience if you want to explore them. Some good visual effects, decent use of the Unreal engine.  I reccomend it. It's a fun game. People obviously spent some time adding the details.

This game is a little bit of a mixed bag  One one side you've got a very one dimensional gameplay feel a lot of the time where you end up doing the same thing over and over but the deeper you look the better the game actually gets. You can find little side missions by just looking around the main base which adds a very slight amount of things to do and the little notes and reports dotted around add to the story.  The missions themselves are also mixed, the gameplay is actually pretty intense sometimes where you actually have to plan out what you want to do next and how you want to approach a level. This is good and the squad is a good idea, I get a similar attachment to my soldiers in the actual X-COM games. The friendly AI can be beyond stupid sometimes however and just move randomly without orders into enemy fire and create loads of problems.  Going back to squads this is an element of the game I enjoy, being able to customise them (although limited) gives the soliders individuality and it's a small touch but changing their weapons and backpacks adds a little bit more strategy to an otherwise normal shooter.  Overall the game's a bit generic in its gameplay but the styling is good and it certainly has its moments, I recommend this on sale to anyone who likes shooters and also the idea of the X-COM series. Maybe for someone who likes the look of X-COM but is intimidated by the strategy of that game.

The 3rd person combat is fluid and fast paced, and strategic maneouvers using squad members gives a good amount of control over how you want to play out engagements. If you decide to play out each choice in the dialog wheel however, you might find yourself listening to ALOT of talking. They give good information about situations, but can be quite a hassle if you're not a big fan of this. Some parts of the story feel a bit rushed or lack context, but flows nicely.  It plays similar to Mass Effect; dialog wheels, a mass effect 3rd person combat feel, and having a sci-fi/alien atmosphere to it.  XCOM DECLASSIFIED IS A PRETTY NEAT GAME.   8.5/10

The Bureau is a very different take on the XCOM universe... it was set in 1960's, height of cold war, when a jamming wave blanketed the nation, and aliens invaded Earth. With comm blackout, information is slow to trickle in, but it appears the nation's military had been crippled, and only XCOM, a command setup to take control in case of full war, is mankind's last hope.   At its heart Bureau is a tactical shooter where you control two other agents to deploy where you want them as well as deploy their special abilities, such as sniper hit, deploy turret, and so on. As the senior agent, you have abilities too, and you'll get more as time go on.   Graphics are quite good and the desolation in the middle of 1960's America is quite evocative. Agents were wearing suits and appropriate hairstyles, esp. the ladies.   There is also quite a bit of dialog, with choices you have to make (and they will affect the outcome, at least a little) a bit like Mass Effect series. Talk to other people in the base, for additional clues, expositions, notes, and whatnot that tells you more about the people you meet. Characterization is quite nice.   Managing the agents during a sort of 'Matrix-like super-slo-mo' mode known as 'Battle Focus' is the key here, where you place the agents at vantage points so they can engage the enemy effectively is key. Flanking is often the best way, as are using the environment such as explosive barrels (yes, that too). As agents gain 'rank' they also gain special abilities they can deploy. The key is to deploy them at the right place at the right time, and that's your job as commander.   The Aliens are nicely animated and sprints into and out of cover and will attempt to flank if possible. However, they are not very bright can can be outsmarted. Later you'll run into bosses, like Mutons and Sectopods (walkers), though most are just Greys. There are occasional elites and commanders. Commanders are tough as they can give shields to other units, but that just makes them vulnerable to strikes when they do that. Add drones, turrets, and you can be in a tough fight.   This alternate history is a lot of fun to play in. It is highly recommended if you like the genre.

I think it's an excellent, fun, accessible game and a great low-impact X-Com game to boot. It definitely takes the franchise in a different fork (more mission and story driven than strategy) but the strategic aspects aren't completely absent and at later levels if you have the difficulty up you actually need to control your agents and position them if you're going to survive.  This is coming from someone who played X-COM and Terror From the Deep on the Amiga back in the day and loved the hell out of them, and I can honestly say I've thoroughly enjoyed the game. It has an LA Noire sense to it, with intrigue and loads of sideplots and stuff you can do if you wander the base and talk to people. I didn't particularly care for any of the X-Coms after Terror From the Deep aside from the X-Com remake, so if you're like me and you like the first two X-Coms and don't necessarily need a heavy squad-management and base builder sim, give it a try.  My only lament is that any gear you want you must discover in missions, some of them completely optional. There is no 'research' beyond what the storyline demands, so the game loses some of the greatness of being able to research and retrofit the alien tech as you recover corpses and such. While it's something I missed in the game, the fact that once you salvage alien technology in the field X-Com can reproduce it for all of your agents is cool.  I'd like to see a sequel to this game made with some more rpg elements like more skill branching, more skill levels, and research and development. Everything else I found to be quite refreshing, especially the timeline which hearkens back to good old Cold War era paranoia, Area 51 and 'the end of innocence'.

Both the spiritual successor and spiritual predecessor to XCOM: ENEMY UNKNOWN, in this thrilling reboot, the enemy is both KNOWN and DECLASSIFIED. Sooo. There's that. Whatever. That's not important. What IS important is that if you can overlook the gameplay, music, and writing, this game was really good! Unfortunately, and with much regret, those three things were included in the game and for some unknowable reason were made integral, and so the final score must suffer slightly as a result.   The ending was very strange with a weird narrative device that would have been interesting in a written format, but felt a little frustrating with you being ripped out of the driver's seat of your own character. All in all this was a pretty good game. The controls could have been mapped better and there could have been a bit more done for the storyline. There should have been a bit more done with the Russians as it was a Cold War era game. There also could have been a wider range of human weapons and the recruitment seemed very limited.  Once you get past that the game does require a lot of tactical flexibility and a bit of fast thinking (I played through on Veteran the first time). With a limited squad size it forces you to pick, choose, and design your tactics for every occasion. The storyline was a bit short but it did do a good job of sucking you in. I found it to be a good first attempt at the game in this style and will be hoping that they do a bit more with the game down the road.

Don't be swayed by the poor metacritic score, it is way better than many had given credit for.  Of course, it is flawed. The graphics are fantastic but not the framerate, nor is the fluncy of the controls. It plays a lot like Mass Effect 3 but it doesn't have that game's slick controls. The controls also isn't very intuitive, especially regarding grenade throwing and the battle HUD. The AI isn't terribly smart and likes to die a lot due to silly moves, and the gameplay is fairly difficult even in Normal.  However, I like the game settings, and being XCOM you're treated with a huge feast of alien graphics. The base is the equivalent of The Citedal on Mass Effect 3, albeit without much interaction with NPCs nor does it have as much events. You can send your squads to seperate missions while you handle the main ones, and it hits me as such a good idea that I wonder why Mass Effect 3 doesn't do this. Then there's the gameplay, which again plays a lot like Mass Effect 3, but one thing that it handles well is cover. In ME3 it can be difficult to know whether you managed to send your squad to cover or just standing before it, but this isn't a poblem here. You can even issue a chain of commands for them to execute sequentially, which is a huge plus.  Try this out before judging it. It is flawed, but still a must have for XCOM fans.

I know this is a very controversial game, hence it's mixed reviews. My son was all into XCOM and I picked this up for him during a Steam sale and he seemed to love it, quickly finishing it and it's DLC. It took me a while, but finally through the magic of Steam Family Sharing, I decided to give it a go. And honestly, to my shock and dismay. I liked it. No, it's not XCOM the strategy game. No, it doesn't seem to follow the established 'lore', such as it is. But if you can approach the game as a tactical rpg-lite squad shooter with a decent story, I think you'll be impressed. For hardcore XCOM fans, think of this as an alternate universe version of XCOM or treat it as it should be, it's own thing. Now onto the review!  +/- Graphics, being built on the Unreal engine, are pretty good. It has some nice particle effects, models are pretty good, and a decently variety of both enemy models and settings. It very much has the 'Bioshock' look to the UI and world, while art direction pulls a good 50's vibe and flavor to most everything. Weaknesses are mostly confined to poor facial animations and sometimes stiff looking movements, but overall the game has a clean and consistent look that works really well for the game.  +/- Story and voice acting is played upon very heavily in this title, far, far more in this title than any previous XCOM game. There are multiple NPC's and your own character that are all developed decently well, if not anything exceptional. You can tell they were heavily inspired by the Mass Effect school of Story but they never quite reach those heights. Most dialog is decently written and spoke well, but while enjoyable, there is no top tier level story telling to be had and much of it feels like it contridicts much of what is presented in the XCOM game. Purists might cry foul and let what is presented distract them, but again, pretend it's an alternate version of the XCOM universe and enjoy the more personal ride.  +/- Combat and powers are obviously the main focus here and this is what drives most people batty. One thing I've learned playing through this entire game is that moving your squad mates is mostly an exercise in futility. Just save yourself some pain and let them move themselves. That doesn't mean you don't coordinate them because this is not a game that you win by playing it as a shooter. Do that and you WILL cry. Powers are everything in this game and using your teams varied abilities is paramount to winning the game.   Using your abilities will greatly slow down time (but not pause), allowing you to choose both your and your teammates abilities and their targets. In this respect (opposed to moving your teammates) the game works very well. Nothing is more satisfying than being pinned down by a sniper, Lifting him out of cover, and focusing fire to take them out quickly. Or taunting an Outsider, which makes them focus on one character and advance, right into a mine dropped by an Engineer. Realizing you can queue up multiple attacks helps you power attack the most dangerous enemiese quickly. I spent much of combat making sure everyone's powers are constantly being used AND upgrading them in a manner that fit my playstyle greatly improved the flow of combat and made the game more enjoyable. I will warn you, as at the start of the game, when you have few abilities, that the game is much more frustrating as the gunplay is at best, competent. This is not a run and gun game - that will kill you fast. Cover, flanking, short bursts, grenades, and abilities will win fights. Nothing else.  This game isn't for everyone, but if you like more tactical FPS, something that's a little different, and something with an interesting 50's take on XCOM, I'd recommend it. You can get it cheap regularly during steam sales and for those sale prices, it's highly recommended. Final score - 3.5/5

A compedent 3rd person shooter with some light rpg elements. This game finally emerged from development hell as has manged to be ok but not great. Lacking polish including spotty visuals, odd dialogue and missing sounds it nevertheless manages to keep you engaged. The sad part is there is a lot of the old game left over that you occasionally get to see what the designers really wanted to make: A character driven, sleuth type story about an alien invasion in the 50/60's. It simply seems that they were over ambitious and ran out of time and decided to make a game with what they had bringing the core back to a third person shooter. Nothing here is overtly bad but there is a germ of a great game that could have been within. Not a complete bust but it is made even more sad knowing what could have been. Pick it up when it's a budget price and enjoy! 7/10

It's a real XCOM. The team's control is not a Rainbow Six, but you can give them the appropriate orders to survive and win on the battlefield. Yours and your team's abilities are really awesome (mine, turret, shield, critical shot, invisibility, etc) and they're really come in handy in the fight. The missions and the maps are various, not just go there, kill that type. I really like running around on the base, talk to everyone, doing side missions. It adds a lot to the game and you'll find out a lot about the backstory. And last but not least, I love the cold war atmosphere.

I found The bureau: XCOM Declassified a very enjoyable game. The story and the setting are quite interesting, but I would advice everyone to play it with the lower difficulty levels. As some people have pointed out, friendly AI is pretty bad, so if you play in hard mode you'll have to reload some of the missions over and over again, making it a frustrating experience. In easy mode, though, you don't have to babysit your squadmates that much and the combat becomes much more fun and interesting.

What to say.. If you're looking for a turn based experiance of squad VS. mobs of alien hoards you may have come to the wrong game but...  I really enjoyed The Bureau. It might not be in the traditional spirit of previous Xcom games.. and feels like a mashup between Mass Effect and Gears Of Wars, but it really seemed to deliver.  The Burearu is a game about the struggle of a classy detective and his squadmates against inhuman odds. The action is live and every order you make counts. The combat is full of tension and adrenaline, and I enjoyed every minute of it. If you're a fan of the Xcom lore and don't mind a deviation in gameplay style I'd definately recommend XCOM declassified.  If you are in it for the turn based mechanic however, I plead with you to wait for the next xcom title, as the active third person shooter gameplay may not be up your alley. It is quite polished and I can not think of a single complaint to make, but it does not follow the gameplay tradition of the games of the series that game before it.  That said, I have played all of The Bureau main campaign before writing this review (save for the post final boss content) and am 100% satisfied with the game save that I wish it was a little longer.

Well, I don't understand all the criticism towards this game. I actually genuinely liked it. It isn't the best game I have ever played, but it is really well done.  First of all, the graphics are incredible - character animations, locations design - everything works for the atmosphere. I just wish they added some elements destruction, such as destroying chairs and tables.  The game itself is third-person shooter with covers and tactical pause during which you can give orders to 2 your companions. There are different companion classes, and they have different skills. I constantly used such abilities as put the turret or use critical shot during my playthrough.  The story starts very slow, but closer to the end it runs so fast and is full or different twists and revelations. Sure, it has lots of cliches, but it isn't that bad. There are even three different endings depending on your choice. When The Bureau was announced, I was super excited, because the trailer looked amazing, the premise of alien attack situated in the USA in 60s as FPS with some tactical elements seemed great. GRAPHICS  are stunning (I played on DX11). Seriously, I´ve never seen a game with better lightning of a scene. I often caught myself just staring on the scene and taking screenshots, because it simply looked beautiful. It required a decent hardware though on HIGH setting, I played on MID-HIGH. On a mission, you can take two agents with you. Each agent can have one of four classes (Engineer, Recon, Commando, Support). I´ve ended up using Support and Engineer (Engineer can put a turret or mines on the battlefield, Support creates a shield, can give a stims to the whole team etc). You have a special class, called Agent. You can Heal, do some kind telekinetics, put a drone on a battlefield, and at level 9 out 10, you can use a mind control ( yea, those are not the agents you are looking for). You can give the commands to your team via command list (imagine KOTOR). At the beginning of the game you will not use it that much, but when the ♥♥♥♥ hit the fan (that means when Sectopod or Muton introduce themselves on a scene), you will beg for mercy and most of the time, you will end up planning what to do, where to put your agents, and wondering how the ♥♥♥♥ you are supposed to kill them all. This game is challenging on a first walkthrough. Not THAT hard, but decently hard.   The weaponry of this game is not too big ( Colt 1911, M14, Springfield, then laser and plasma variations, grenades), but nothing to complain, the main power of this game is within the abilities/perks of the team).  One thing bothered me though. A.I. of the squadmates. There are not dumb, not really, but they are not shooting much when no order is given to them, and they do not roll out when a ♥♥♥♥ing grenade is under them! That was the only thing that was frustrating me. 8.5/10  STORY  is decent, nothing original of course, but it drives you towards the end, because you will want to know what the hell is happening here (or ... well, THERE). The main character, William Carter, is and old school badass agent with some serious issues from the past, but when the ♥♥♥♥ needs to be done, he is called for duty. I do not want to spoil anything, so let´s just say that story is kinda 'mass-effectish'. 7/10   FINAL VERDICT  I enjoyed this game very much, it was challenging, with not original, but interesting story. Together with awesome graphics and gameplay, I must say to the world - ♥♥♥♥ METACRITICS. I do regret that I didn´t bought this game at launch but on Summer Sale, and it´s shame that there will be no sequel ( the game was not succesful in terms of sales) 9/10

As I wasn't expecting a typical X-COM strategy game, I could really enjoy this third person tactical shooter. It has a great, well-written story, taking place in a very detailed and atmospheric US 60's world. Even though at first the protagonists of the game seemed to be very clyche (the smoking, drinking, I-don't-give-a-♥♥♥♥ anti hero, the I-have-to-do-what-has-to-be-done commander, the ice queen female agent and, oh, don't forget the immigrated Nazi scientist), during the story they appear to be diverse and deep characters, with their own past, problems and motivations. Due to their interactions, the story holds some big surprises during the last third of the game...  Another big plus are the battles: All missions are unique, with scripted events, discoveries, ambushes, some horror atmosphere and a great design. I enjoyed them much more than the unpersonal, repeating missions of X:COM Enemey Within. Nevertheless, this is a subject to your own preferences. You also have to use a lot of tactic in this game, however, the action is much more intense, as your squad is right in the middle, while explosions, bullets and laser beams are flying right around you. The agents have interesting abilities, and even the developing super powers of the main protagonist are logicallay explained during the game.  A lot of people critizise that the research part and the autopsies are held very simple in the game. Well, you are playing a SENIOR AGENT, not the BASE COMMANDER, so personally I would have wondered if I would have decided what research comes next, which alien we will cut first wide open to look after his bowel and so on. Therefore, you can talk with the scientists in the lab about their progress, watch them testing and developing new weapons (with some hilarious scenes) and interogate an outsider personally, having the chance to build up some sort of personal relationship with him (or you can beat the ♥♥♥♥ out of him).  To make a long story short: If you are looking for another turn-based X:COM strategy game, with all the typical elements of this series, like research, base building, autopsies, and all other base commander's responsibilities, you will not be happy with this game.  But if you want to enjoy the beginning of X:COM through the view of a senior agent, if you are happy to play through an intense and well-written story, if you want to interact with interesting characters and you like action, though tactical battles, and all that in a very authentic 60's setup, you really should give this game a try!

If you want a TLDR review: this is Mass Effect's combat system 1:1, in Mafia I-II world, with enemies from XCOM:EU. Nothing more, nothing less, and with a few spots that could have been better.  First of all, the story is close to non existent. Basicly everyone is functional as role that keeps an undercover agency working, instead of having any kind of personality. This isn't a negative thing, it's not why we ever liked any XCOM for, and this one isn't any different - until the very end. That where the devs decided to go for Mass Effect 3 storytelling, and not only they achieved a similar, but an even worse disaster of things that doesn't make sense anyhow, even on a single character's decision level or as game in a whole. Or just basic logic. But, this is mainly the last hour, and you'll have about 10-13 before that. How's that?  That part, is actually great. Just don't even think about touching a console controller or playing on normal difficulty. The combat is really challanging, smart and tactical, later on however can become slightly automatic and boring even on Veteran difficulty, just because you naturally reached better technology, levels and abilities. Other than that, it's like you have a dream Star Wars: Republic Commando, just not Star Wars, and there is more customization to it. Which leads me to my last point where I can throw anything bad on this game: customization. XCOM:EU could have been better on visual customization of our soldiers (and it's sequel is really good looking on this part!), but Declassified is another step back from that. You can change names, 3 or 4 colors on a suit, and that's it. When you recruit a new agent, you can also choose from ~8 premade faces, plus skin color. You cannot have women as agents, or customize visual looks, which is really a miss because you are not supposed to blend in to the crowd, you meet noone but aliens anyway.  Overall: Declassified is good, as an average good game can be. It has some unique touches here and there, the action depending on your chosen difficulty level can be really great, but it's one of those games that have absolutely great gameplay, but nothing else. The story is non existent, the customization in it's current form is really hurting that it's not deeper, the characters are throwaway faces. And that's totally fine for XCOM:EU that is a strategy game, but the whole reason Declassified exists as it is, is changing the perspective and bringing it down to a personal level of a group of agents, and it's a failure at that. If there is ever a sequel on this and they can improve on that, it's potentially GOTY material. For this, it's great, but you have to know why you buy it, to not have expectations the game cannot meet. My only problem is, that it still tries, and does it bad. But that's only the last hour, don't let me made you back off if you are thinking about buying it. That means you are looking for a good, really tactical TPS. Declassified, is really good at that.

The monotony of the cover shooter model is spiced up by the XCOM series trademark commander interface, which slows the action down and allows you to assign cover positions to your squadmates, coordinate their abilities and set up traps. The learning curve is steep, and particularly on the highest difficulty mode, you'll feel like a hapless crew of redshirts more often than not. However, once you've got the basics down and acquired a few handy-dandy abilities such as your main-character's mind control power, most encounters become a less inspiring rinse-repeat affair. For me, this was a welcome return to the world of half walls. I haven't really been thrilled with cover mechanic games since Vanquish, but this I enjoyed. It shares a lot of similarites with Gears of War based on mechanics, all the same joys and ills. However, my biggest complaint with Gears, is the overly drab, too much machismo, stupidity that permeates the characters, the story and the gameplay. The sci-fi paranoia of this is much more engaging, and doesn't turn me off. The colour palette and retro feel is more refreshing, too.  Additionally, The Bureau distances itself from Gears with squad controls, and various perks. The perks are almost all fun and engaging to deploy across all the various classes, and there were a couple of missions where I just let my squad and their perks take charge. However, with every squad command game there are issues: here too, your squad will move from the cover you've placed them to freelance a bit, even if they've taken minimal fire, hopping into the open to get roasted. If they manage to survive this gambit out from cover, another issue comes into play. Whether its moving a squadmate, or deploying a perk, it must be steered across a path that a human can travel. This sometimes means you can't get your squad to quickly hop back over a wall they just jumped, and sometimes you can't trhow deployables over half walls.  Overall though, this is a very competent cover mechanic game with light squad strategies, playing somewhat similarly, but perhpas more robust than the later Mass Effects.  For those who dismiss it because it isn't XCOM, or XCOM: Enemy Unknown, you're right, it isn't, not even nearly, but that's gaming royalty, too. You'll see some familiar aliens from the franchise, and be told a decent narrative that is almost so disconnected from XCOM that it won't impact your experiences with that game either way. I say sit back, enjoy a fun, light romp through alien paranoia of the atomic age.

It all looked very promising, but failed at execution.  There are many elements lifted from Enemy Unknown, but none of them really made an impact. There are still full cover, and half cover, but it doesn't make any difference, not that I've noticed. You get shot when you peek out or when flanked anyways. So why bother.  Slow down time is cool, and a kind of throwback to original - you prepare your strategy, how to attack, what abilities to use etc, but once that first surprise attack is over, it's back to cover shootings. Trying to control the battlefield and flank the enemies rarely works as they move in real time and react to your movement. The only strategy is to shoot until they all fall down, starting from biggest threat (obviously).  However, the biggest disappointment for me is enemy variety. XCOM was always brimmed with it. Here, you have sectoids, outsiders (a bit different design - ok, whatever), muton, drone and that's it. Turns out Outsiders are main antagonists, as a whole alien race. There are technicians, psy, ghosts, elites blah blah... even bosses look just like regular foot soldiers with a bit more variety in armor. Where are chrysalids, Thin men (Which would work well in story as the ones that take human or agent form) Uber Etereal as final boss? So disappointing...  Oh, and no matter what squad mates you bring with, it always ends up with you killing the most of bad guys - so, another fail. They each have their set of abilities, and more as they level up, but rarely do they turn the tide. Maybe on highest difficulty - but what I've played, it was all about me.  Running around XCOM HQ is tiresome, conversations sequences rarely have any outcome no matter what you chose to say, and weapons go through ammo fairly quickly. You often run around looking for ammo - during the battle!  As for good things - graphics really made an impact on me. It really looks nice. The scene where alien ship exits space portal is wow, and the 60s settings is spot on. However facial impressions are bland, and lip sync is almost comical.  Story is OK, but lacks a bit more depth. No one explained to me what that thing on my arm is...  As for recommendation. Hard to say... It was disappointing, but in the end I enjoyed playing it - sort of. Maybe someone who knew nothing of XCOM before and how much potential this game had, he may view it for what it really is. 6/10

The Bureau: XCOM Declassified isn't bad, it just isn't very good. It's a bit threadbare, feeling like several incomplete ideas that have been rushed out the gate.  Realistically, I suspect The Bureau was completed on a small-ish budget after lingering around in development hell for a few years. Something about the game makes it feel like it's ten years or more old, if it wasn't for some of the DirectX 11 effects looking so sparkly it'd be easy to think it was from the early 2000's. Many of the locations are bare and empty places, feeling like they've been built in a rush, and often with several such vacant sets stitched together without any combat or events to distract, assumably to give the impression of covering a lot of ground in a mission. Other areas have clearly had some time and attention spent on them, and the locations and missions waver back-and-forth on this attention / quality scale, leaving the experience feeling quite jarring. You'll wander from a well-realised street, strewn with debris, bodies and signs of previous life... into an area that feels like it's been imported from a PS2 game.  The mechanics of the game basically play out like Mass Effect's combat, or Mass Effect 3 more specifically. It's a cover-based shooter where you run around with two squadmates, you have abilities with cooldowns, can issue orders and give movement directions to your squad. Enemies come in multiple varieties, some with shields and some with armour, with a few enemy types creating interesting tactical choices (a unit that supplies shields to all other nearby units, for example, if taken out the shields drop and make the fight easier). Unfortunately, where Mass Effect shines in making you care for your squad, here they are just flat cardboard bodies waiting for you to pull their puppet strings. They also keep respawning in front of you whenever you cross through a 'loading door' (frequent area transitions where the game loads the next section as your character very slowly opens a door and looks left and right before giving you control again), which is a bit distracting.  In fact, I felt the game lacked polish in general. I fell through the level geometry and died twice in eight hours of play, once whilst just running down a straight corridor. Audio logs can be found and played, although walking away from them they fade until inaudible (if I have to stand still to listen to them, they may as well be written text!). The controls aren't terrible, but movement feels clunky and stiff, for example; when you run there is absolutely no strafing, not even in a limited fashion, leaving you to clumsily course-correct with your mouse as you charge forward. You also tend to pop in and out of cover randomly at times, especially if strafing in cover, and controlling your squadmates feels awkward (fortunately the game slows down time during this).  Much of the story is told over radio as you run between fights, although there are some cutscenes that deal with exposition. The game also uses a dialogue wheel, just like the Mass Effect series, allowing you to choose between being vaguely rude or agreeable, it's a nice enough touch, although it felt a bit redundant with such small scope for actual meaningful choice. Levels are basically linear paths that open into combat arenas, the main missions last 30 to 60 minutes each, with side missions from 15 to 30 minutes roughly (I only did a couple, they felt fairly pointless). The game isn't overly long with six main missions, the story is mildly amusing with some interesting characters (although the main player character really started to grate on me). The plot felt like it tried to raise the stakes too high a number of times implying that Earth has basically been wiped out and already lost by the midway point of the game, then later claiming it's not as bad as implied, which breaks the suspension of disbelief somewhat.  Imbetween the missions, the game flirts with the idea of being an XCOM-style strategy game where you pick missions and kit out your squad, but with only six main plot missions and (I believe) seven side-quest 'minor missions', it doesn't feel like there's a lot of variety or choice. The equipment feels limited, with only a handful of weapons to equip and the only other equipment slot being a 'backpack' which acts as a kind of modifier for ammo, health regen, or ability cooldowns.  Overall, not a bad game, just not a particularly good one. It feels like it didn't succeed at being the mixture of genres it wanted to be, and it's not particularly good at being any ONE genre either. The plot is so-so, and the clunky and unpolished feel doesn't help. But if you don't mind all this and want a simple squad and cover-based shooter, this might entertain.

tl;dr So, I 100%'d this game for Achievements. It would probably take me about 10 less hours, but idling in menus added a bit. If you're going for achievs, this is an easy game to get them all in... The only other time I would suggest this game is if you're a HUGE fan of XCOM and you NEED the lore. 5/10  Long Review  Alright, this game is rough. It's like the developers of Mass Effect wiped their ♥♥♥ with the extra funding they had from the ME series, and churned out a ♥♥♥♥ show of a game called The Bureau: XCOM Declassified. This. Is. Rough. The worst part is, you can often times see the potential this game has. It's a game that WANTS to be good, WANTS to be a fan service... But it falls flat so, so early. The main character is a boring, rude, monotone agent who constantly bounces between 'caring', and 'shut up, we have a job to do'. His 'personality' actually adds to the overall failure of this game, I feel. The cover system is atrocious. You are either super glued to your cover, or you can't get into cover, on a game solely based around Third-Person Cover Shooting. Like I said, Mass Effect with a pennies worth of funding. That gets really infuriating when you're on the highest difficulty and some of the enemies advance to flank you, and you're bashing the multitude of buttons to get off cover and nothing is happening. The abilities are boring and unimagitive... Once again, comparing to Mass Effect, they pretty much ripped off the abilities. Lift, Pulse Wave, Weaken... Jeeeeeeeeeeeez. The guns are all boring, with little personality in each one. I could beat the game using the M1911 pistol, to be honest, since it seems to deliver one hell of a headshot. In fact, most of the guns feel like they do NOTHING. You're tickling a Sectoid with your Scatter Laser. wat. Running around the HQ QUICKLY becomes tedious. You have to run back and forth, back and forth, etc. etc.   Pros: XCOM Lore A nice 'old school' feeling... They did somewhat decent on that Interesting view into some of the aliens Killing an alien every now and then results in some funny physics Decent graphics and audio  Cons: Terrible controls Boring abilities and guns Tedious legwork in the HQ Sticky or repelling cover Repetitive gameplay to the maaaaaaaax. Trying out new guns, new squaddies, or new ability combos don't add at to the experience at all.   Go play XCOM: Enemy Unknown/Within, or any of the older XCOM's. They'll probably offer the same lore in a different style, and they will actually be good.

In an alternate timeline: The year is 1950. Donald Draper never joined Sterling Cooper to work as an ad man, he remained in the army and rose through the ranks. Eventually recruited by the CIA, he becomes involved with The Bureau, and helps fight off an alien invasion of Earth. Thats this game in a nutshell: Donald Draper shooting aliens.  The gameplay is fun, at first. The Third person shooter + squad combat is neat on the first mission, when you get agents with all their abilities unlocked. But then it takes that away and you have to -slowly- level them up again. Gameplay is largely the same, fighting the same 2 aliens over and over again, except when they occasionally throw in a muton or sectopod battle. Also, one of the big bosses froze up on me and just sat there as my squad gunned it down. Long set peices showing off the devestated cities lead up to cover based combat sections in a predictable pattern. For some reason, there's more ammo than you can carry in the areas without enemies.  The characters suffer from a bad case of rubber face, and the shot-reverse-shot dialogue trees become tedious very fast. Which sucks, because apparently a bunch of content is hidden in the speech you go through in the base.   It's a cool game in premise, but it doesnt quite live up to what it could have been. A few tweaks and a little more though into varying gameplay would have gone very far in making this better. Although it is a totally different game, XCOM Enemy Unknown does a better job at Squad based alien killin fun. I got this in the Humble Bundle, so its okay for the price, but I wouldnt recommend buying this game straight up, unless it's on sale.

What I got was basically all the most boring parts of Mass Effect's combat system, and a story that couldn't be more forgettable. Combat isn't tactics, it's patience. It is incredibly hard to die, and if you do your completely replaecable squadmates will usually be able to revive you. Enemies take forever to die, most boss fights devolving into you running around looking for ammo as your teammates slowly tick down their gigantic health bars. The ability to customize your companions is very limited, you can only change their guns and add an enhancement item that reduces damage, cooldowns, etc. Oh, and you can change the color of their suits.   The story doesn't make you feel any sort of emotion, it's just Mission X and Agent Y, mixed with a 60's thematic and sci-fi cliches. The X-Com headquarters is kind of neat, but once you realize there is nothing to do there it loses some charm. Maybe it gets better in the last third of the game, but I have a hard time believing dessert will be excellent after spooning down so much gruel.   As I said, I was very high on this game based on the trailers and the excellence of its strategy counterpart, but there is nothing in the execution of this title that backed up that promise. Of my 6 hours, I don't think I had fun for more than 5-10 minutes, and I don't think I will ever play it again. I bought it at ~50 dollars, and a month later it was on sale for 19.99. This game is a practice in strangely borrowed and hybridized mechanics, and an endearing yet offput spinoff of the franchise.  First and foremost, if you're a fan of XCOM for its tactical gameplay, this isn't your game. All of the combat is cover-based third-person shooter, and real time apart from the time-slowing assess mode which allows you to give commands to your 2 squadmates, and carefully select combat skills. I liken the combat greatly to Mass Effect, decidedly more clunky, and with an oddly bloated crosshair -- as if UI designers expected I'll forget where my gun is pointing.  From a franchise and lore point of view, the game takes place during the Cold War with a 'Noir' theme, harkening back known alien scum like the sectoids and mutons (which are actually scary to fight now, especially on a higher difficulty) and brings forth some new flavors, including a new take on the squaddie-slaying Sectopod. However, being put into the odd 'shadow war' that they are is a bit lop-sided and obviously noncanonical in comparison to the other XCOM games where invasion is clearly apparent, and you are the first and last line of Earth's defense. Technological advances are also not particularly as 'exciting' and the taken-for-granted nature of them from first mission of the game and there on breaks the 'immersing' factor of getting new toys.  Two very specific peeves of mine are; 1. There is no manual saving. You hop between checkpoints throughout the entire game, and this harms the unpremeditated whims of playing it. This can also lead to going through cut scenes, dialogue, and entire 'homebase intervals' than you already just went through. 2. Squadmates are finicky in cases, with AI that needs to be babysat routinely. They do not comprehend the sense of not poking their head out while under enemy suppression (which can lead to them quickly losing non-regenerable health), they do not use their skills of their own accord (yet perhaps for the better with their AI), and in my experience, have occasionally 'forgot' orders to hold ground while I'm trying to cover their flank, and are very dodgey with taking out targets you mark them to attack.  I intend to still play it now and then, because it has a few elements from Mass Effect that I enjoy (including dialogue wheels) but I'd never recommend it to someone who is a fan of other XCOM games.

An X-Com game turned into a 1960's based Mass Effect style game, and not in a good way. It's like ME2 and 3 in that the mainline, gun combat has had too much focus. Upgrades do not reflect weapon tech level (bullets, laser, then plasma), where as soldiers can, at the start when you only have the starting weapons, have tech for, say, a turret, that uses tech based off of the alien's weapons. Any and all choices you make (and side missions) will have 0, repeat, 0 impact on the story, as (SPOILIER) X-Com HQ eventually gets attacked and destroyed, killing virtually everyone inside of the base save for some major characters. The whole idea of 'having to take alien weapons that haven't been destroyed by operator death using the Venn Brace (the device on Carter's arm in virtually all screen shots)' is just stupid. The AI isn't the brightest. The game also lacks a key aspect of X-Com and it's choices: will this work out in the long run.  Lets use X-Com: Enemy Unknown for example: You recieve an abduction mission. You have to pick one of three. One is in St. Petersburg, and Russia is offering a new sniper, at the rank of captian. Your's is a squaddie, as you had to replace your previous one. Then there's one in New York. The US is offering 4 scientists. You have completed all projects that will be fast, and are on a long term one (10 days left). Then you have one in Cairo. Egypt is offering 200 credits. You recently bought a satilite, and still have room for one more. Europe and NA has their panic raised to 2, amd if you don't pick it, it will raise to 4, hanging on the edge of full panic and risking leaving, or staying. The sattilite construciton is cutting the montly report close, but you may have time to place that sattilite over the one of the paniced countries. And there MAY be a chance of a Terror mission. What I have given you is a typical scenario, in both EU and EW. The player may think this: 'That sniper is good, it can make my squads stronger, and I don't have to worry about my normal sniper becoming wounded. But, I need those Scientists so I can research Plasma weapons faster, make my soldiers better in the field. Although, I could use those funds, and can use two sattilites to lower more countries panic.' For this, there is no right or wrong answer. And there is a chance that this can make or break your run.  However, for the Bureau, there are no hard choices. You can do as many side missions, and send as many side agents out before you continue on with the story. The even added a cliche 'character sacrifice' on the finally mission, (SPOILER) having you pick between Agent Weaver, Director Faulke, or Doctor Weir (depending on who you picked to continue as in the level prior). There is no sense of loss, as you can't even use the character you just rescuesed, esentially giving you a hollow choice.  This game was labeled an X-Com game and had potential. It did not live up to it.

The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is the imagination of a classic series of turn based strategy games as a first person shooter. The game begins in Pima, New Mexico where strange happenings are afoot and suddenly a coordinated alien strike disrupts global communications, supply lines, etc. The Bureau is an over-the-shoulder shooter with a “time-slow” button that allows the player to give commands to their squad. Those who have played the Mass Effect games … the combat is exactly like Mass Effect.  The Good: The fights in this game a pretty fun. Good battlefield layout made for lots of fun fights as you slip from cover to cover. Further, the ability to move your squaddies and deploy skills and hardware gave a neat strategic over lay that made the game more than just a “shoot-em-in-the-head-over-and-over” fest (in lower difficulties).  The Bad: Sadly, everything else is ranging from not good to terrible. The entire game is one long hall way; there’s never two ways to a fight, a way around a fight, etc. The story … well dang, I am honor bound to never spoil anything no matter how good or how bad I think the writing may be. That said I’ll be interested to talk to someone else who’s played this to see if the whole last 10% of the game was actually as bad as it seemed of it is super wonderful and I’m just a dope and didn’t get it … IDK, not worth playing again to find out. The voice acting is mediocre at best and the tech-tree (or extreme lack thereof) is downright offensive to anyone who’s played the older X-Com games (there is no tech tree, you find a weapon just sitting there and pick it up … yours now). The game is also SO comically straight forward that you almost have to avoid the “secrets” since they are mostly shiny things at the end of short hallways, like … you can nearly see them from the main rout! Just in case you actually did miss anything the stuff in these “secret” passages you can take comfort in that it is either ammo you didn’t need or a gear schematic that they game will give you later. This game also commits the cardinal sin of game difficulty: enemies get more HP and do more damage / run a head-shot script per level of difficulty which turns the game into a “shoot-em-in-the-head-over-and-over” fest.   The Funny: The game was also not bug free which, when games are bad, can be nice since it serves as comic relief. I fell through the floor of places I was walking toward twice and once the camera locked onto my face and didn’t move after dialog. The combat raged on and I proceeded to just sit there, adoring the main characters steely grimace while getting gunned down for being out of cover. OH! Whether or not you play the game though, be sure to look up the commercials! The marketing for this game was more fun than the entire game! Seriously, the stuff they did on Twitter and small webisodes and such were SUPERB! The marketing people for this deserve to be on much better projects that’s for sure! I’d hire then in a snap!  The Summary: I give this game 5 out of 10. It’s not quite as bad as when they made Shadowrun into FPS but this is pretty bad. Think of a game like Chess. We know it as a game where strategy and a careful, mistake free execution are keys to success. Then take the strategy out and let all the chess pieces run anywhere they want and shoot! That’s what you get when you turn a game like X-Com into an FPS. If you want to sit down and shoot at aliens for a few hours while you watch TV and the game is on Steam-sale for 5 bucks or less you won’t kick yourself for picking up a copy, I’ll give it that. With all the good titles out there though I can’t imagine anyone so hard up for something to do that this would be a good buy. The fights are fun if ya like a quick shoot-em-up but that’s all I can say. Thank God Sid Meyers got the rights to this game as well and made a FANTASTIC turn based strategy X-Com; that is everything X-Com should have been! GET THAT ONE INSTEAD!

I'm torn on this game. First, the movement is a bit awkward. I played the game clear through on the hardest difficulty and I never could master the controls on it. Combat was alright. Nothing special as far as tactical shooters go but the AI's movement felt pretty well natural with my squad even giving enough space to avoid the entire team being wiped by a single grenade (most of the time). What almost kills the game for me though is the dialog and 'choices' in the game. I don't know if it's a bug or just bad writing but throughout the game the choices I made seemed to be ignored for a standard plot line. Spoiler:   For instance, I saved Nico and helped him recover from the sleeper virus but repeatedly he is referred to by other characters as if he had died. Honestly, I don't even see how saving him had any real impact on the game or story.   Additionally, the dialog jumps as characters will use a term or reference an event that they haven't heard yet or wouldn't have known which breaks any chance at becoming immersed in the game. Beyond that, I'm at a loss for where this game fits in with the XCOM universe. I honestly think that after hearing the game pitch, someone at Take2 said, 'Hey, cool alien invasion game idea. You know what, we have the XCOM license, let's slap that on for some extra sales.' It's the only explanation I can come up with that doesn't place this game into a different universe as Enemy Unknown/Enemy Within due to inconsistencies in plot lines, how different certain species are portrayed from one to the next, and no feigned attempt at explaining why we don't start Enemy Within with plasma guns and UFO technology.  Despite the flaws, I don't regret the purchase. I would be highly selective on which friends I'd recommend it to since it will take a forgiving player to like the game and even then I'd say wait till it's on sale. Since I can't recomment it to the general public, I have to give this game a thumbs down. The Bureau is a mish-mash of half ideas and borrowed concepts that never comes together. The gameplay and structure is reminiscent of the Mass Effect games: You start in a base, pick a mission from a map, grab two followers and go on a third person cover-shoot with light tactical squad elemets. Damage on the field is like XCOM: done based on the kind of cover the enemy is in, meaning unless you can get a head shot it is necessary to flank enemies in order to effectively dispatch them.   This all sounds fine in theory, the problem is execution. The game does not have the interactive story elements of Mass Effect, nor the interesting characters. Squad-mates taken on missions are randoms with no personality, meaning they are little more than a set of skills accumulated throughout the game. If they die, they're dead forever and trying to level a new squadie late game is tantamount to suicide since they can't take more than a couple of hits. Their AI is questionable at the best of times: Orders to do a flanking manoeuvre typically result in them making a B-line across an open killzone and if you move too far from them, they break cover and jog directly back to you, regardless of circumstance. This forces you to micro-manage them constantly as you can't trust them with even the most basic of orders.   Admittedly Mass Effect doesn't handle these combat elements much better but it gives your character more personal power to handle combat situations whereas The Bureau strips you of them. Mass Effect makes using your allies and their questionable AI an option while The Bureau makes it a necessity without compensating the decision, punishing you with perma-death if you attempt to get creative or if the AI spazes out.   The story is OK on it's own but as an XCOM prequel it makes no sense and ends with an unsatisfying meta-element which I won't spoil. The initially charming 50's low-tech setting becomes bland as tile sets are frequently reused and gives way to generic alien ship backdrops.  Mass Effect distracts you from it's inadequacies with a more complete package of interesting characters, interactions and locations. If it didn't have these things it would only be a semi-competent cover shooter, which is what The Bureau is.

Addendum: I can't progress past the first mission due to the game crashing at the elevator scene in what I'm assuming to be the first mission aside from the beginning of the game. Overall the gameplay itself is not really enjoyable, as a third person action shooter it doesn't feel satisfying in the least. There presentation and atmosphere of the game is kind of neat in a way but only when the game actually kind of works.   Honestly, I don't recommend this game.

Maybe next time.

After the first couple missions I was psyched to see where this game might take me, but after playing for about 2 hours, I had already seen all that the game had to offer. I don't regret getting this game because I didn't put much time into it and I really like Xcom games and 3rd person shooters. The game itself, barely kept me entertained long enough to give me the desire to launch it.

I really like the XCOM games. I played the first ones released many many years ago and I really welcome that they have blown new life in the series. The Bureau takes on another approach than the other games, which is interesting. However, I feel like that the challenges in this game appeared at the wrong places. Research is not a thing in this game, you just get upgrades 'for free' as you progress through the game. It almost feels like it comes to easy compared to the other XCOM games. The challenge instead is to keep your team mates in order. The AI of the team mates is really terrible. Terrible to the extent that I have stopped playing the game. It becomes such a choir to keep them under control that you can not really be effective in a fight. Even if you put like 95% focus on trying to keep your team mates alive, at some point you may have to relocate yourself because enemys are closing in, or flanking you, and instantly that leaves your team mates unattended for long enough for them to run out of the cover your ordered them to stay in and run straight up to the most dangerous enemy and die - rendering them impossible to revive. Because if you run out there yourself you are dead as well. However, you need the team mates that you have invested time in levelling up and unlocking skills for. Sm it's a deadlock.  IMO opinion the stupidity of AI is a game breaker and I grown so tired of it that I don't know if I will ever finish this game. I stopped playing 8 hours in to the game and have been unable to motivate myself to continue for about 3 weeks now.  To this end, I can not recommend it. It's nice with variation from the other XCOM games, I like the atmosphere and the looks of the game. But the AI is, like I said, a game breaker.
